questions.question: Which of the following is a disadvantage of potentiometric titration?

answers.a: Turbid, fluorescent, opaque, or colored solutions can be titrated.
answers.c: Mixtures of very diluted solutions can be titrated.

questions.question: Q2. Which of the following is an inappropriate use of an acid-base titration curve?

answers.a: To select a suitable primary standard for the titration.
answers.b: To determine the concentration of the base.
answers.c: To determine whether the acid is weak or strong.
answers.d: To select a suitable indicator for titration.

questions.question: Q3. Which of the following reference electrodes is not suitable for the electrochemical analysis at a temperature above 80<sup>0</sup>C?

answers.c: Either silver-silver chloride electrode or calomel electrode.
answers.d: Neither silver-silver chloride electrode nor calomel electrode.

questions.question: Q4. Which of the following is a requirement of an indicator in potentiometric titration?

answers.a: An equivalence point that is close to the stoichiometric point.
answers.c: The ability to change from colorless to pink.
answers.d: A transition point that is close to the equivalence point.

questions.question: Q5. What is the use of quinhydrone ?

answers.a: To determine the hydrogen ion concentration or the pH of a solution.
